segment.description: I am a 30-year-old woman.
I am here because of a 3-day history of joint pain in my hands and a rash over my chest and arms.
The joint pain in my hands has persisted and is exacerbated by writing or typing. I rate the pain as a 3 on a 10-point scale.
My medical history is unremarkable and my only medication is an oral contraceptive.
I am in a monogamous relationship with my husband. I do not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use illicit drugs.
I do not have any known allergies.
My vital signs are temperature 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse 94/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 107/58 mm Hg.
No laboratory studies were mentioned in the question stem.
I am a 34-year-old woman.
I have a 1-month history of worsening right upper quadrant abdominal pain and discomfort.

The pain is described as a dull ache and is not affected by eating or defecating. I have not experienced nausea or changes in appetite or bowel habits. The pain is constant while I am awake, but it rarely affects my sleep. Acetaminophen provides occasional relief.
I have been otherwise healthy with an unremarkable medical history. My only other medication is an oral contraceptive.
My vital signs are normal.
Abdominal examination reveals hepatomegaly but no palpable masses or evidence of cirrhosis.
Results of liver function tests and serum α-fetoprotein concentration are within the reference ranges. Serologic studies for hepatitis B and C are negative.
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 4×4-cm mass in the right lobe of the liver.
I am a 12-year-old girl brought to the emergency department by my mother.
I have a 1-week history of worsening swelling in my legs.
I also noticed blood in my urine yesterday, but it has not recurred.
I had an upper respiratory tract infection and sore throat 1 week ago that caused me to miss several days of school. Otherwise, my medical history is unremarkable and I take no routine medications.
Menarche has not yet occurred. My BMI is 20 kg/m².
My vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 78/min, respirations 12/min, and blood pressure 136/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 100%.
Results of urinalysis show: Protein: 150 mg/dL, Blood: Positive, Leukocyte esterase: Positive, Nitrite: Negative, WBCs: 5−10/hpf, RBCs: 10−25/hpf, Casts: 1−2/lpf.
I am a 45-year-old woman who has noticed during the past several months that my fingernails have become white, increasingly brittle, and seem to lift off my nail beds easily.
I have also had episodes of feeling warm and perspiring.
My medical history is remarkable for intravenous drug use 25 years ago. I currently take only a multivitamin.
Last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. I appear thin and mildly anxious.
My vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 106/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 136/92 mm Hg.
Physical examination of my hands shows a white discoloration of the nail beds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
I am a 48-year-old man.
I come to the clinic because of a 10-year history of recurrent, intrusive thoughts that my house will be broken into and damaged by criminals or accidentally destroyed by a fire when I am not home.

These thoughts have worsened during the past 2 months. I now spend 4 hours daily checking that the doors and windows are closed and locked and that the stove and oven are turned off; I previously spent 2 hours daily doing these tasks.
I say I cannot keep a job or leave the house very much because of the amount of time I spend checking these things.
I have no other history of serious illness and take no medications.
Physical examination shows no abnormalities.
On mental status examination, I have an anxious mood and a sad affect. I am fully oriented. I am not having hallucinations or delusions.
I am one of the two hundred patients with fibromyalgia who were randomly selected from a large neurology center for a study on the relationship between stress levels and fibromyalgia-related pain.
My chief complaint is fibromyalgia-related pain.
I am asked to maintain a daily schedule of my fibromyalgia pain and stress levels for 30 days using two well-validated and reliable self-reporting scales.
During recruitment for the study, a baseline interview was conducted to obtain sociodemographic and personality data from me.

Results of the study show a positive and statistically significant relationship between stress levels and fibromyalgia-related pain (P<.05). Similarly, statistically significant relationships were found between Type A personality participants and increased stress levels (P<.01), as well as increased levels of fibromyalgia-related pain (P<.005).
I am a 12-year-old boy with sickle cell disease and type 1 diabetes mellitus.
Type 1 diabetes mellitus was diagnosed in me 6 years ago. Since that time, I have been treated with insulin and dietary management.
The family recently moved to the area.

His insulin regimen has not changed during the past year; however, his mother says he has been only marginally compliant with his insulin and dietary regimens. His diabetic diary shows home fingerstick blood glucose concentrations ranging from 140–200 mg/dL during the past 3 months. He admits to checking his glucose concentrations infrequently. Measurement of hemoglobin A1c obtained last week was 5.4%.
My vital signs are temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 72/min, respirations 24/min, and blood pressure 110/64 mm Hg.
Physical examination shows no abnormalities.
I am a 35-year-old man who has been a patient at this office for the past year.
I am here to request that a copy of my medical records be sent to another physician in town.
I have an overdue account balance of $750, which I have not paid for several months.
I signed an office form authorizing release of health information and provided the name and address of the other physician to whom I would like the records sent.
I am a 47-year-old man.
I am admitted to the intensive care unit because of lower gastrointestinal bleeding.
I have a history of alcohol-induced cirrhosis.
Physical examination shows marked ascites and splenomegaly.
Results of laboratory studies show: Serum Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL, Hematocrit 29%, Hemoglobin 9.7 g/dL, Platelet count 105,000/mm³, PT 25 seconds, INR 2.5.
I am a 57-year-old woman who is scheduled to undergo laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
My father has stable angina and my mother has rheumatoid arthritis. My grandmother has Parkinson disease.
I do not smoke cigarettes or drink alcoholic beverages.
My vital signs are normal.
No laboratory studies mentioned in the question stem.

During the interview, my face is expressionless. I have a flexed posture and am unable to open my mouth wide. I am 173 cm tall and weigh 81 kg with a BMI of 27 kg/m2. Physical examination discloses thickening and hardening of the skin over the dorsum of my hands and forearms, as well as mild kyphosis. Strength testing shows no abnormalities; muscle tension is normal. Passive and active range of motion of my upper extremities is full. My gait is slow and deliberate. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities.
I am a 32-year-old man.
I have a 10-day history of a red rash that has spread over my entire torso.

The rash is not itchy or painful. I had a flu-like illness nearly 5 weeks ago, with associated headache, neck stiffness, muffled hearing, and a canker sore on my tongue. All of these symptoms have resolved without treatment.
Additional medical history is unremarkable and I take no medications.
My BMI is 18 kg/m² and my vital signs are normal.
I have been experiencing symptoms of nasal congestion, sneezing, nonproductive coughing, and eye irritation.
There was a fire in the school several weeks ago with significant smoke and water damage to classrooms, the cafeteria, and the school ventilation system.
Several teachers and support staff have reported having the same symptoms as me.
None of the children had fevers.
No similar outbreaks have been reported in the community.
I am a 20-year-old man who has been your patient since early adolescence.
I come to the office at the request of my family for an examination 1 day after a motor vehicle accident for which I was at fault.
I was arrested for the third time after police discovered I had been driving under the influence of alcohol.
I have a history of truancy, shoplifting, and two attempts to run away from home. I dropped out of high school in my senior year.
I have been unemployed for the past 8 months, and as a result I have many unpaid debts. I seem unconcerned about my current difficulties and have no plans for seeking employment or paying my debts.
Vital signs are not provided in the question stem.
Laboratory studies are not mentioned in the question stem.
I am a 45-year-old man who works as a limousine driver.
I am here for an initial appointment because I would like you to fill out and sign a legal document at the request of my attorney.
I am filing a lawsuit against the limousine company that employs me because I developed post-traumatic stress disorder following a motor vehicle collision.
I am a limousine driver and I am filing a lawsuit against the limousine company that employs me.
I appear irritable and tense as I provide my history.
I have developed post-traumatic stress disorder following a motor vehicle collision.
I relay my symptoms by reading them aloud from a written list.
I am a 39-year-old woman.

I am here because of gradually increasing shortness of breath while doing my usual household activities. I also have fatigue, a feeling of heaviness in my chest with exertion, trouble sleeping, and the very recent onset of a rapid heart beat and fluttering in my chest.
I was always sick as a child.
I do not smoke cigarettes.
My father died of a myocardial infarction at age 55 years.
I did have some shortness of breath at the end of my second pregnancy.
I have an irregular pulse of 130/min.
There is a prominent diastolic rumble heard best over the apical area of my heart.
Lungs are clear; there is no hepatomegaly or pretibial edema.
I am a 10-year-old boy with a traumatic brain injury sustained during infancy.
I am examined in the nursing care facility because I have had no urine output during the past 24 hours.
During the past 4 days, I have had decreasing urine output, intermittent fever, rhinorrhea, and cough.
As a result of my brain injury, I have severe developmental delay and a seizure disorder.
I am fed orally, but I am nonverbal and nonambulatory.
My medications are levetiracetam, docusate, and multivitamins.
My vital signs are temperature 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 25/min, and blood pressure 110/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 95%.

Results of my laboratory studies show: Serum Blood Urea nitrogen 78 mg/dL, Creatinine 3.2 mg/dL, Na+ 131 mEq/L, K+ 5.6 mEq/L, Cl− 88 mEq/L, HCO³ −16 mEq/L, Urine Specific gravity 1.030, Creatinine 90 mg/dL, Na+ 8 mEq/L, Hematocrit 37%, Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL, WBC 12,000/mm3, Neutrophils, segmented 60%, Lymphocytes 40%, Platelet count 250,000/mm3.
I am a 27-year-old man who came to the office with my wife.
I came to the office because of a recent episode of loss of muscle control.
I was at a reception, someone told a joke, and when I laughed, my legs collapsed. I recovered in a few seconds and did not lose consciousness.
I have a long history of sleepiness and I am able to go to sleep quickly. I usually awaken feeling refreshed after a short nap.
I have no history of similar episodes or hallucinations.
There is no family history of similar problems.
My vital signs are normal.
Physical examination shows no abnormalities.
I have been working in a shipyard for the past 50 years and have been exposed to asbestos.
My health insurer has provided claims data that documents all chest x-rays and diagnoses of mesothelioma among current workers and retirees.
The study enrolled shipyard workers who were diagnosed with mesothelioma and shipyard workers who were not diagnosed with mesothelioma.
All subjects in the study had to have chest x‐rays.
I am an 88-year-old man with osteoarthritis.
I have a 2-day history of severe low back pain and inability to walk.

I have not fallen and do not recall any trauma to my back. Five years ago, I underwent bilateral hip replacement which improved my pain and mobility. However, my symptoms have worsened during the past year. I am most comfortable using a wheelchair for ambulation but can walk short distances with a walker and assistance.
One year ago, carcinoma of the prostate was diagnosed, but I declined therapy.
I am experiencing point tenderness over L3 through L4, and S1 in my lower back. X-rays of the lumbosacral spine show lytic lesions and compression fracture.
There is no mention of any family diseases in the question stem.
I have declined therapy for my carcinoma of the prostate and expressed my wishes to be kept comfortable.
There is no mention of any allergies in the question stem.
My vital signs today are temperature 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse 88/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 188/66 mm Hg.
The patient refuses additional diagnostic studies.
I am grimacing with pain and holding my lower back.
The daughter fears that I will be 'abandoned' if I am not evaluated for additional treatment.
I am a 23-year-old man.
I have a 7-day history of fever, crampy abdominal pain, and diarrhea.
My abdominal pain worsens with oral intake and I have been having 8 to 10 episodes of diarrhea daily.
My medical history is unremarkable and I take no medications.
I do not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use illicit drugs. I am not sexually active.
My vital signs are temperature 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse 118/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 108/58 mm Hg.
A stool culture is obtained, and empiric pharmacotherapy is initiated.
I am a 23-year-old man who came to the office because of a 7-day history of fever, crampy abdominal pain, and diarrhea.
The abdominal pain worsens with oral intake and I have been having 8 to 10 episodes of diarrhea daily.
My medical history is unremarkable and I take no medications. I do not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use illicit drugs. I am not sexually active.
My vital signs are temperature 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse 118/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 108/58 mm Hg.
A stool culture was obtained and results showed growth of Campylobacter jejuni.
I have not traveled recently and have had no sick contacts.
I have had pain and swelling of my left knee during the past 3 days. The pain worsens with weight bearing and I rate it as a 6 on a 10-point scale.
There is no mention of any family diseases in the question stem.
There is no mention of any childhood diseases in the question stem.
There is no mention of any allergies in the question stem.
I am a 46-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1.
I am here because of a 2-week history of black discharge from my right nipple.

I had mammography and ultrasonography of the breasts 2 months ago for evaluation of increased glandularity, palpated in the upper outer quadrant of my right breast, noted at my most recent annual examination.
My medical history is otherwise unremarkable and I take no medications.
My vital signs are normal.
The studies showed likely benign findings with recommended follow-up in 6 months.
Palpation of my right breast discloses glandularity in the upper outer quadrant but no other masses. There is scant, black discharge from my right nipple.
I am one of the 600 individuals with a specific disease who were included in a trial involving the use of Drug X.
I have a history of using Drug X as part of the trial.
There is no mention of any family diseases in the question stem.
There is no mention of any social diseases in the question stem.
There is no mention of any allergies in the question stem.
There is no mention of vital signs in the question stem.
There is no mention of laboratory studies in the question stem.
I am a 23-year-old woman brought to the emergency department by my friend.
I am experiencing headache, vomiting, and diarrhea that developed rapidly 6 hours ago.
I also have fever, chills, generalized muscle pain, and diffuse rash.
I previously was healthy and have had no known exposure to anyone who has been ill. My only medication is an oral contraceptive.
I do not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. I drink one to two alcoholic beverages weekly.
I am disoriented to person, place, and time.
My vital signs are temperature 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse 114/min, respirations 26/min, and blood pressure 82/44 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 90%.
Results of laboratory studies show ALT: 164 U/L, AST: 130 U/L, WBC 14,300/mm³ with left shift, Urea nitrogen: 57 mg/dL, Platelet count 52,000/mm3, Creatinine 2.2 mg/dL.
I am a 68-year-old man with a 4-week history of increasing stiffness in my shoulders and upper arms.
I have been unable to play golf in the morning because of the stiffness, but it somewhat improves in the afternoon. I have also been feeling fatigued and sometimes 'headachy and feverish'.
I have arthritis in my knees treated with acetaminophen, which has not relieved my shoulder and arm pain, and hyperlipidemia treated with pravastatin.
I am a retired radiologist.
My vital signs are temperature 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse 76/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 145/80 mm Hg.
Results of additional laboratory studies show: Serum Blood Creatine kinase 88 U/L, Hematocrit 36%, Hemoglobin 12.0 g/dL, WBC 8600/mm3, ESR 88 mm/h.
I am a 16-month-old girl who was brought to the emergency department by emergency medical technicians.
I am here because of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that began 25 minutes ago and has continued despite administration of 0.5 mg/kg rectal diazepam 10 minutes ago.
I was at home at the time of the seizure. In the emergency department, I was given an additional 0.5 mg/kg dose of diazepam intravenously and the convulsion terminated.
My medical history is unremarkable. I take no medications.
My temperature is 39.1°C (102.5°F). My oxygen saturation dropped to 75% and I appeared cyanotic. My respirations are 10/min and shallow.
I received bag-valve-mask ventilation, followed by intubation and mechanical ventilation.
I am a 32-year-old woman.
I came to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fatigue and postural light-headedness. I also have nausea with one episode of vomiting this morning.

My stools and urine have been darker than usual lately. I have stage III-B Hodgkin lymphoma and started the first cycle of chemotherapy 8 days ago. I am currently taking ferrous gluconate, hydrocodone, and prochlorperazine. I am receiving 0.9% saline at 75 mL/hr.
I have stage III-B Hodgkin lymphoma.

My vital signs today are temperature 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse 76/min supine and 80/min standing, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 125/65 mm Hg supine and 120/60 mm Hg standing. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%.
Results of laboratory studies: Hematocrit 24%, WBC 2400/mm3, Platelet count 78,000/mm3, Specific gravity of urine 1.032, Bilirubin and RBC in urine are negative.
I am a male neonate who was born at 36 weeks' gestation 2 hours ago in the labor and delivery unit of the hospital.
I am now showing signs of respiratory difficulty.

My mother, an 18-year-old primigravid woman, smoked one pack of cigarettes daily throughout her pregnancy. She received prenatal care during most of the pregnancy. One episode of chlamydial cervicitis was detected during the last trimester and treated with azithromycin.
There is no information provided about family diseases.
There is no information provided about childhood diseases.
My mother had one episode of chlamydial cervicitis during the last trimester of her pregnancy.
There is no information provided about allergies.
My vital signs are temperature 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse 150/min, and respirations 70/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%.
Chest x-ray shows prominent pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the intralobar fissures.
I am a 26-year-old woman.
I came to the office 1 day after passing bloody mucus with my stool.
I noticed mild abdominal cramping and some constipation preceding the episode.
My father had colon cancer and died at age 48 years from metastatic disease. An aunt died of an unknown abdominal tumor.
I have been under considerable stress because I am anticipating the defense phase of my PhD thesis soon.
My only medication is acetaminophen for occasional headaches.
My temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg.
My abdomen is mildly distended, nontympanitic, and tender to palpation only in the right lower quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding.
Pelvic examination shows no masses or mucosal lesions.
Rectal examination elicits pain and bloody mucus.
I am a 15-year-old girl brought to the office by my parents.
I have a 2-month history of progressively worsening gait disturbance.
I have fallen several times, once striking my head and causing a brief loss of consciousness. My parents mentioned that I have had behavioral changes during this time.
I have asthma treated with a corticosteroid inhaler as needed.

My family history includes multiple sclerosis in a maternal aunt, parkinsonism in my paternal grandfather, and cancer in several paternal relatives, including a grandmother who died from a hemangioblastoma.
My vital signs are normal.
Toxicology screening of my urine is positive for marijuana and cocaine metabolites.

I am awake and alert, but I avoid eye contact and will not answer questions. Auscultation of my lungs discloses expiratory wheezing. Cardiac and abdominal examinations disclose no abnormalities. I have mild bilateral papilledema. My stance and gait are wide-based, and I am unable to perform a tandem walk.
I am a 70-year-old man brought to the emergency department by my son.
I have a 2-day history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, chills, and confusion.
I have vomited twice during this time despite decreased food intake.
I have hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide.
My vital signs are temperature 40.2°C (104.4°F), pulse 110/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 100/60 mm Hg.
Results of laboratory studies show: Serum amylase 350 U/L, Bilirubin total 2.1 mg/dL, WBC 16,500/mm3 with prominent immature forms, Neutrophils segmented 42% total, Neutrophils bands 25%.
The patient appears seriously ill without evidence of jaundice. Abdominal examination discloses tenderness to palpation over the liver without guarding.
Medical and surgical history is otherwise unremarkable.
I have no history of social diseases.
I have no known allergies.
I am a 70-year-old woman who is experiencing worsening tremor of my hands.

The tremor has been present for most of my life and initially was mild, occurring only when I was tired or stressed. However, during the past month, the shaking has become more noticeable and frequent. I am now embarrassed to eat with other people because of how obvious the tremor has become.

My medical history includes essential hypertension controlled with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia controlled with atorvastatin. I have been taking fluoxetine for the past 3 weeks to help me cope with the death of my husband 2 months ago. My only other medication is occasional ibuprofen for joint pain.
I used to drink one to two alcoholic beverages monthly, but now I drink one glass of wine daily because I believe it reduces my tremor.
My vital signs are temperature 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 130/85 mm Hg.
Complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, and serum thyroid function tests have been ordered and results are pending.
I am a 70-year-old woman.
I am here because of a 1-month history of gradually worsening shortness of breath.
My medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia.
I am currently taking atorvastatin and lisinopril as routine medications.
My vital signs are temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse 122/min and irregularly irregular, respirations 28/min, and blood pressure 144/88 mm Hg.

My laboratory studies show: Urea nitrogen 29 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL, Na+ 142 mEq/L, K+ 4.1 mEq/L, Cl− 99 mEq/L, HCO3− 24 mEq/L, Glucose 102 mg/dL, Hematocrit 38%, Hemoglobin 12.9 g/dL, WBC 7800/mm3.
There is no information provided about my family diseases.
There is no information provided about my social diseases.
There is no information provided about my childhood diseases.
There is no information provided about my allergies.
I am a 67-year-old man.
I suddenly develop severe abdominal pain.
My postoperative course had been uncomplicated until 4 days ago, when I developed a low-grade fever. I have been unable to tolerate a full liquid diet during the past 4 days.
My medical history is remarkable for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and a myocardial infarction 6 years ago.
I have smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years, and I typically drink three to five beers daily.
I have no known allergies.
My vital signs now are temperature 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse 68/min and regular, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg.
My serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. My leukocyte count is 15,800/mm³ with mild left shift. My urinalysis shows no abnormalities.

Physical examination shows bilateral cataracts. Auscultation of the chest discloses diffuse mild wheezes and a grade 1/6 soft systolic ejection murmur at the cardiac apex. Palpation of the abdomen discloses mild to moderate mid and right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness. There is no guarding, rebound, or palpable mass. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Peripheral pulses are normal. Neurologic examination discloses no abnormalities. ECG shows an old inferior myocardial infarction. Chest x-ray shows scarring at the left and right cardiac bases; no masses or infiltrates are present.
I have a history of hypothyroidism and I take levothyroxine for it.
I am experiencing progressive dyspnea and wheezing for the past week.
I also have a racing heart and I am coughing up a small amount of blood-streaked sputum.
My vital signs are temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse 132/min, respirations 32/min, and blood pressure 135/78 mm Hg.
Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 92%.
I am a 70-year-old man.
I am admitted to the hospital through the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of severe nausea and four episodes of vomiting of undigested food.
During the past week, I have had worsening nausea, heartburn following meals, and early satiety.
My medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 20 years ago, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension.
On admission, I appear uncomfortable.
My vital signs are temperature 36.2°C (97.1°F), pulse 102/min, respirations 16/min, and blood pressure 105/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%.

Results of laboratory studies ordered in the emergency department are shown: Serum Blood ALT 23 U/L, AST 26 U/L, Alkaline phosphatase 85 U/L, Amylase 104 U/L, Urea nitrogen 42 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.32 mg/dL, Hemoglobin A1c 8.2%.
I am a 70-year-old woman who is here for an annual health maintenance examination.
I have been experiencing slowly progressive fatigue, diffuse muscle aches, and generalized pain for the past year.
I have a history of osteoporosis diagnosed 5 years ago.
I am currently taking alendronate and calcium supplementation.
My vital signs are normal.
My physical examination is unremarkable for my age, with no point tenderness on palpation.
Results of complete blood count, serum electrolyte and thyroid-stimulating hormone concentrations, liver function tests, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are all within the reference ranges.
Screening mammography and colonoscopy done 1 year ago disclosed no abnormalities.
I am a 22-year-old man.
I am here because of a 4‐day history of cough productive of green sputum as well as fever, chills, and rigors.

I also have had a 3‐day history of progressive shortness of breath; I now have shortness of breath at rest. I was evaluated in an urgent care center 1 day ago and was prescribed azithromycin, but my symptoms have worsened.
My vital signs are temperature 39.1°C (102.3°F), pulse 138/min, respirations 40/min, and blood pressure 103/56 mm Hg.
Results of arterial blood gas analysis on 100% oxygen via nonrebreather face mask are shown: PO2: 50 mm Hg PCO2: 44 mm Hg pH: 7.34 Oxygen saturation: 85%.

I am using accessory muscles of respiration. I am diaphoretic and am able to give only one- to two-word answers to questions. Skin is mottled and there is cyanosis of the fingers and toes. Pupils measure 4 mm in diameter and are reactive to light. Mucous membranes are dry. Auscultation of the lungs discloses bilateral crackles. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities.
I do not have any history of social diseases.
I do not have any known allergies.
I do not have any significant family diseases.
I do not have any significant childhood diseases.
I am a 33-year-old male physician.
I am reporting for a shift in the emergency department.
A nurse alerted that he noticed a faint odor of alcohol near me. When approached, I appear tired and more disheveled than usual. There is an odor of alcohol on my breath.
I have no known history of substance or alcohol use disorder.
I am married with three children, and my wife is pregnant with twins.
I was recently hired and have had no actions on my license by any state medical board.
N/A
N/A
I am a 60-year-old man with a 1-year history of progressive left groin pain.
The pain is worse with exercise and is relieved with rest. It even hurts when I'm turning over in bed.
I have had generalized mild stiffness of my joints during the past 3 years. I take atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia and lisinopril for hypertension.
I do not smoke cigarettes. I drink one alcoholic cocktail daily.
My vital signs are temperature 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse 82/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 120/78 mm Hg.
I walk with a slight limp and have difficulty changing position. Abduction of the left hip elicits pain. Physical examination of my other joints discloses no abnormalities.
I am a female patient who is participating in a 2-stage screening program for ovarian cancer.
My chief complaint is the need for early detection of ovarian cancer.
I am currently undergoing screening for ovarian cancer to catch any potential issues early.
I have a history of regular gynecological check-ups and screenings.
There is a family history of ovarian cancer in my relatives.
My vital signs are within normal range during the screening process.
I am undergoing laboratory studies as part of the screening program to detect any abnormalities.
I am a 35-year-old woman.
I am here for follow-up of chronic pelvic pain.

I have had deep pelvic pain since undergoing total abdominal hysterectomy and radiation therapy for treatment of cervical cancer 5 years ago. The pain is constant, severe, and aching, rated at its maximum as a 10 on a 10‐point scale. It worsens during intercourse.
All subsequent cancer follow-up has been negative. Otherwise, my medical history is unremarkable.
I have smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. I do not drink alcoholic beverages.

I have taken oxycodone for my pain for 3 years, but now it only partially relieves my pain. I request either an increased dose of oxycodone or a change in my prescription to controlled-release morphine, which was recently given to me by a friend.
My vital signs are normal.
I appear lethargic. I am oriented to person, place, and time but speak slowly with slurred speech.
Examination of my skin shows no abnormalities.
My pupils are pinpoint and react sluggishly.
I am a 35-year-old woman.
I am here for follow-up of chronic pelvic pain.

I have had deep pelvic pain since undergoing total abdominal hysterectomy and radiation therapy for treatment of cervical cancer 5 years ago. The pain is constant, severe, and aching, rated at a 10 on a 10-point scale. It worsens during intercourse.
All subsequent cancer follow-up has been negative. Otherwise, my medical history is unremarkable.
I have smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. I do not drink alcoholic beverages.
No information provided in the question stem.
My vital signs are normal.
